content.description: A fun face climb. Reasonably sustained. A slightly junky start soon turns to good rock.
content.protection: TR - 2 bolts
content.location: Tunnel Bluff - West Face. This climb is  to the left of Locomotion essentially sharing the same start. It is also  close to  directly above the west tunnel entrance. Can be reached by a slightly sketchy traverse from Jigsaw base heading to the right. It's easier and not sketchy to reach the climb by hiking  from the tunnel up and around on the right side. After 20-30 yards cut left on a slightly used trail to the base of the climb. But most climbers would rap down anyway. This climb is listed in the  excellent guidebook by Pagel/Kollath : Superior Climbs (out of print). There are 2 bright shiny bolts on top directly above this climb. Easily reached from the left or the right. Note that Pagel listed this climb as an 11a but both my climbing partner and I onsighted it and felt it easier than that. The topo in the guidebook for this climb is not as detailed as normal so it's possible we were not exactly on the route intended by Pagel. Just follow a line of holds below the bolts and you'll have fun regardless of the rating. Note also that the line drawn on the picture is approximate from memory and may not be exact.

climbs.name: Waking Up In Duluth
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Felix Hörmann, 2 August 2009

content.description:
Tunnel Bluff South West Face. The crux is probably finding a dry, mosquito free day, but this climb, despite the controversy it may create from the local climbing ethics police will be enjoyed by many. It is fun, clean (for the moment!), and well protected. No "set ups" required. 

  Pitch #1: Get immediately into the beautiful right facing dihedral finger crack, jog right to a bolt and surmount an overhang (awesome movement!) ending on some slab moves to a two-bolt belay. 5.9, 15m.
content.protection: Set of small camming units (C3s or TCUs), Nuts and QDs for 3 bolts.
content.location: Tunnel Bluff South West Face. Hike to the landmark tunnel as described. Hike up a small path on the right side (south) for 2 minutes to the base of the route. One may elect to start climbing directly from the path or scramble up a few meters to belay below the right facing dihedral crack.

content.description: Free-soloable
content.protection: big holds and ledges for feet
content.location: A bit to the left of "The Dihedral" (outside of far/east tunnel entrance)

content.description:
From Superior Climbs: "Although its not a bad route, this climb is rather particular because it is neither obvious nor direct; its sort of like always being off route. Best advice: when in doubt, step right." 

 Additional commentary: Anchor up top can be made pretty far back from the wall. There are multiple variations that look more fun than stepping right. They look more difficult than and with worse pro then if continuing right. Would not recommend leading.
content.protection: gear and natural anchor
content.location: The far right side of the northeast bluff, up the right angling cracks.

content.description:
The crux is the beginning, hard to figure out how to start. Work your way around a small roof and go straight up.

 Note: A set of glue-on bolts were just placed for sport (not sure who set them or if they were done correctly, the first bolt is about 12-15 feet up). There was a set of TR anchors up that got used but were determined to be unsafe and cut off on 3/26/20.
content.protection: 4 Bolts + gear in bottom and after 2nd bolt.
content.location: Just to the left of The Bulge. Look for a small roof and sport bolts placed all the way up.

climbs.name: Static is a Four Letter Word

content.description: Face climb between Simple Corner and Beginners Crack.  Easier if you are tall.
content.protection: Small rack or TR.
content.location: Between Simple Corner and Beginners Crack on the Tunnel Bluff.

content.description: Right facing cornerleft of New Corner.  Easy and not really worth the effort to lead...many people solo this but be aware that it is still 5th class (maybe 5.3...) and a fall will do a lot of damage.
content.protection: Small rack, solo or TR
content.location: First climb right of the "access gully"

content.description:
Eric and I played around on this, as well as some other local climbers (Sean Taylor, Guy Evans,etc) so I am not sure on the FA. 

  Crimps up to a funky flaring pod to jam at mid-height, which is the crux.  Finish straight up
content.protection: TR, to lead would be R/X
content.location: Located about 10 feet right of Coming Unhinged.

content.description: Smear and stem your way to the overhang then reach up onto the face to a solid left facing layback.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts
content.location: Follow the cliff climbers left of the Dislocation Overhang area for a couple hundred feet.

content.description: A large bulge with plenty of hand and foot placements, good for beginners to have a go at some rock.
content.protection: Toprope, slings and things.
content.location: To the right of The Dihedral, climb the bulge in the rock.

content.description: Corner and crack just left of Bionic Finger Crack.  Easy climb - great first lead as the gear is solid the whole way.
content.protection: Nuts and a few cams to #3 Camalot (C4)
content.location: Tunnel Bluff - Left of Bionic Finger Crack - the OBVIOUS left facing dihedral.

content.description: A stemming chimney. Start is a little junky but fun moves in the climb.
content.protection: Gear to 4" with emphasis on small and medium. Gear is slightly sketchy in places but not bad enough for me to call it PG13. I just placed extra. I went to the right of the recent rock scar down low - my climbing partner later commented I might have had better gear staying left of the rock scar.
content.location: Tunnel Bluff - West Face. This climb is a steep slot close to  directly above the west tunnel entrance. If already at the cliff it can be reached by a slightly sketchy traverse from Jigsaw base heading to the right. It's easier and not sketchy to reach the climb by hiking  from the tunnel up and around on the right side. After 20-30 yards cut left on a slightly used trail to the base of the climb. This climb is listed in the  excellent guidebook by Pagel/Kollath : Superior Climbs (out of print). There are 2 bright shiny bolts on top directly above this climb. Easily reached from the left or the right on top if toproping.

content.description: The route starts with a flake undercling over a roof and then starts  up a shallow dihedral just right of the left arete. Then pretty much go straight up staying right of the arete the entire time.
content.protection: I didn't look at the pro much but it would be poor (ignoring the bolts). There are some new bolts that I believe represent a combination or hybrid of "Kindly Step Aside" and "Take Two, They're Small" if you follow the bolts but I did not study the bolts all that closely.My understanding of the route lines comes from the excellent Pagel/Kollath guide : Superior Climbs (out of print). Dave Pagel did have the first ascent per the Mike Farris guide.
content.location: On the left margin of the wall left of "Take Two, They're Small".  The climb for the most part is 3-4 feet right of the left arete. Note that another line can be climbed just to the left of this one that does go directly up the arete at about the same difficulty. We climbed that also.

content.description: Just to the right of Dislocation Overhang, this face climb is fun and not too obvious.  If leading you'll need to use the crack of Dislocation for gear...better yet, just TR from the same anchor
content.protection: TR or same rack as Dislocation
content.location: A few feet right of Dislocation Overhang - Tunnel Bluff

content.description: A good climb up an obvious and sharp flake that creates a dihedral.  Straight forward climbing but the crux could easily result in a broken ankle if you fall on lead (foot jam, not ground fall...)
content.protection: Cams and hexes to #3. Bolts for TR above.
content.location: Northwest Bluff

content.description: Located on the Tunnel Bluff, start up toward the obvious roof above a big ledge (Bionic Finger Crack is to the left).  Straight forward climbing to the ledge with tons of protection (small to medium cams and nuts).  The Crux is at the roof and requires a layback on some slick rock.  Commiting move but easy to protect with a #2 Camalot and a long sling.  After pulling the overhang gain the crack and enjoy the easy jamming to the top.   Fun little climb with lots of protection for beginning leaders.
content.protection: Small to medium cams and a set of nuts.  Medium cams for anchor at top.
content.location: The only obvious overhang on the Tunnel Bluff...

content.description: Straightforward dihedral climb, easy moves to the top.
content.protection: Toprope, slings and things
content.location: Walk through the old railroad tunnel and look to your right for a 90 degree dihedral

content.description:
on the left/south wall, just outside the east/far entrance to the cave.

 Looks fun and interesting from the ground, but the rock quality is terrible. I was trying to be careful and rocks/debris came crashing down more than once.

 This route should not be climbed, since the rock quality is lousy.
content.protection: Belaying from 50 feet back
content.location: see above.

content.description: Just right of the Flake; if you set it up right, you can climb both of these from the same anchor.  Climb just right of a small roof, and follow the left facing corner, as it gets progressively harder, to the top.  A nice climb that packs a punch for the grade.
content.protection: TR, Has also be led - R or X.
content.location: Climber's right of the Flake (5.7).

content.description: Fun route and good lead for the difficulty. The easiest route on the NW Bluff Follow the right facing crack all the way up. Starts off as a 5in off-width for about 10 feet until theres a good jug. The cruxes are at the off-width at the start and the slopers at the top. The route is a little run out between the roof and the ledge to the right. Rock quality is good.
content.protection: Protection to 2 inches. The anchor requires either a .75, 1, or 2 in the rock and a double length sling for the tree
content.location: This route is located 130 ft WNW (left) of The Bulge on the NW Bluff, past the access gully. The first right facing corner that looks climbable is it. To get down take the access gully on climber's right or walk off on climbers left.

content.description: The Pagel/Kollath guide : Superior Climbs (out of print) describes it as a "flake, face, and jam crack" but doesn't show a detailed topo.I climbed up to an undercling and traversed right to a flake with a wide crack (4"). At the top of the flake I traversed left on a ledge to a topout crack. This seems to match the Pagel description and looks like the most enjoyable climb in that immediate area.
content.protection: Gear to a #4 Camalot. Extra 3-4" gear for the bottom if you like to sew it up. Trees on top for anchors.  The trees are not huge and the one closest to the climb is dead.
content.location: Just right of the access gully that is left of Beginner's Crack. The climb starts on the upper tier. Pagel decribes it as "about thirty feet to the left of Simple Corner".

content.description: An easy TR set-up or a good lead, this route follows the first obvious crack line to climber's left of The Flake.  With excellent technique, this route goes fairly easily.  Without, it can get difficult quickly.
content.protection: TR
content.location: Left of the The Flake, follows a crack system through a small dihedral and roof.

content.description: A nice route that has multiple difficult sections - not a one-move wonder. Start up and left - then move back right and up to a short, difficult, dihedral. The traverse right can be done either low with the feet just above the roof or you can climb up and left farther before traversing right. I suspect the feet just above the roof is the original route.
content.protection: TR - I didn't even look at the gear but suspect it would be R or X.
content.location: Northwestern BluffJust left around the corner from The Bulge. See the photo.

content.description: Bionic Finger Crack is located on the Tunnel Bluff just to the left of Dislocation Overhang.  The climb shares the same easy first 35 feet (5.5) as Dislocation and then veers left up the obvious little seam.  Look for the little pocket, which will be of little use, and then try to jam your fingers into the seam and pull up.  If you are leading, your fingers will be in the placements and placing at waist level will be a trick.  Try to work your toes into the seam or toe hook the corner.  Smearing seems like a good idea and would be if the rock had any friction! It's short, but sweet and will make you feel like a real dude!
content.protection: Top rope or a few nuts in finger-tip size.
content.location: A few feet to the left of Dislocation...shares the roof so look for the only overhang.

content.description: The crack in the center of the face just left of New Corner.  Easy but a good lesson on crack technique.
content.protection: Nuts or cams to 2 inches.
content.location: Left of New Corner, right of Simple Corner.

content.description:
Ely's Peak is Duluth's prefered home crag and lays within the Duluth City Limits.  Climbs are short and relativley straight forward with a mix of crack and face climbing on solid basalt.  There are two areas here as well as some bouldering.  Climbs on the Tunnel Bluff are about 60' and closer to 45 or 50' on the Northwest Bluff.  Duluth and the northshore area have a chalk free and bolt free ethic, though a few crags have started to sprout bolts.  DO NOT BOLT at Ely's Peak and please leave bolting at other crags to the locals as folks up here are super senstitve about ethics.  In general, DO NOT BOLT is the area.   The local schools and camps occassionally host classes at Ely's Peak so be prepared to share the crag.  Mornings are generally quiet.   All climbs are easily top-roped and a few are good trad leads.  Although there are a couple of stout routes here, the bulk of the climbing is in the sub 5.11 range with most of the classics (if such short climbs can be called such) in the 5.6 to 5.8 range.   Worthwhile climbs include Dislocation Overhang (5.6) and Bionic Finger Crack (5.12a) on the Tunnel Bluff and Corner Geometry (5.6), The Flake (5.7) and The Bulge (5.8) on the Northwestern Bluff.   Get gear at W-Trek Outfitters or Vertical Endeavors and get beer at the Brewhouse, all in Duluth.     Make sure to follow the new climbers access trail just left of the Superior Hiking Trail to access the climbing...DO NOT cut across the private property. 

  This area has access issues - make sure you know where to park so you do not get towed...also, the DNR is issuing tickets for trespassing so stay on the climber trail!!!
